Consider a system governed by the Laplace equation \\( \\Delta u = 0 \\), defined on a bounded domain with Neumann boundary conditions. We focus on the Fourier transform of \\( u(t, x) = e^{pt}v(x) \\) where \\( p \\) is a complex number and \\( v(x) \\) solves the Laplace equation.

Knowing the Fourier transform \\( \\hat{u}(T, k) \\) at time \\( T \\), is it possible to determine directly which parameter (\\( p \\) or \\( q \\)) was used before and after the intervention at \\( t_1 \\), without additional data?
Explanation: The Fourier transform \\( \\hat{u}(T, k) \\), though indicative of changes, does not hold unique signatures of \\( p \\) or \\( q \\). Without explicit temporal markers or separate knowledge of the intervention dynamics, it is insurmountable to pinpoint the precise contribution of \\( p \\) up to \\( t_1 \\) and \\( q \\) thereafter just from \\( \\hat{u}(T, k) \\). Multiple combinations of parameters can result in similar transforms, leading to inherent ambiguity in backtracking the exact sequence of events or interventions.
